title: 15. The Sophists and Rhetoric
description: The role of the Sophists in shaping rhetoric, education, and intellectual life in classical Athens.

questions.question: Why was Athens a natural centre for teachers of rhetoric?
options: Because of the importance of public speaking in the Assembly

questions.question: What did Plato most strongly criticise about Sophistic rhetoric?
options: Its disregard for truth in favour of persuasion

questions.question: In Plato’s Gorgias, how does Gorgias describe rhetoric?
options: The most powerful skill of all

questions.question: What claim does Gorgias make about the skilled orator?
options: He can defeat experts before ignorant audiences

questions.question: What wider role did the Sophists provide in Athens?
What range of subjects did Sophistic education cover?
options: A wide range of academic fields

questions.question: From where did Gorgias come when he first arrived in Athens?
In what capacity did Gorgias initially come to Athens?
For what skill was Gorgias particularly renowned?
What event does the Encomium of Helen address?
Which four forces does Gorgias argue could have compelled Helen?
What is Gorgias’ central argument about Helen’s responsibility?
options: She was the weaker party in all scenarios

questions.question: Why does Gorgias compare persuasion to physical force?
options: To show speech can compel like force

questions.question: Why is the Encomium of Helen important to historians?
options: It is a rare surviving work by a Sophist

questions.question: Which prominent Athenians were reportedly impressed by Gorgias?
What does Plato’s hostility suggest about the Sophists’ influence?
options: They threatened traditional education and values

questions.question: Overall, what impact did the Sophists have on Athens?
options: They contributed to Athens’ intellectual depth
